How does Verus ID compare to traditional blockchain-based signing methods, and what additional capabilities does it offer for digital identity management?

Traditional blockchain-based signing methods, such as those used in Bitcoin and its derivatives, allow users to sign messages with specific private keys that can be verified against public addresses. While this provides some limited signing capability, it lacks critical features that make it suitable for use as an actual digital identity. In particular, traditional blockchain-based signing methods do not provide a way to recover from loss or theft of private keys, which is a major limitation.

In contrast, Verus ID offers a more comprehensive digital identity management solution that goes beyond simple signing capabilities. With Verus ID, users can create a digital identity that includes features such as friendly name aliases, modifiable multi-sig signing, updates, and privacy. Additionally, Verus ID enables the association of signed attestations by other identities to statements about properties of the identity, which adds an extra layer of trust and verification.

One of the key benefits of Verus ID is that it enables free verifiable digital signatures for all, which is a fundamental capability that can be built upon to create more advanced applications and services. Overall, Verus ID provides a more robust and feature-rich digital identity management solution that addresses the limitations of traditional blockchain-based signing methods.

Bitcoin, which was first to enable worldwide, P2P decentralized blockchain transactions, and most of its derivatives, offer ways to sign messages with specific private keys that can be verified against public addresses. While that does offer some limited signing capability, it does not offer capabilities that can compete with centralized services offering more sophisticated key management. A single public/private key pair lacks critical capabilities to make it suitable as an actual identity, most notable and obvious being the ability to recover from loss or theft of private keys, but arguably as important are friendly name aliases, modifiable multi-sig signing, updates, privacy, and the association of signed attestations by other identities to statements about properties of the identity.Verus ID enables free verifiable digital signatures for all through the Verus ID protocol as just one of the many new capabilities it enables. It is also the foundation upon which many new applications and additional capabilities can be built.
